awd_titl_txt: Phases and phase transitions of quantum gases on optical lattices
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical research in condensed matter and quantum many body theory, concentrating on phases and phase transitions which are difficult to realize in materials but may be possible to realize with cold atoms in optical lattice traps.

Cold atomic systems can emulate the behavior of electrons and atoms in real materials. They can be used to create atomic counterparts of known condensed matter phenomena, or to study yet unexplored and undiscovered new states of matter. 

Feshbach resonances allow real-time tuning of interactions among the atoms, while optical lattices emulate crystalline lattices through which electrons typically move in real materials. These tools were used separately in the past to create atomic analogs of superfluids with variable interaction strength and atomic equivalents of phases of condensed matter systems possible on a lattice, such as Mott insulators. 

The PI will investigate the outcome of combining the two tools. It is expected that atomic systems placed in optical lattices whose interactions are controlled by Feshbach resonances will exhibit a variety of phases and phase transitions among them, including superfluids, band and Mott insulators, topological superfluids at high transition temperature, and new types of topological phase transitions, as well as unusual one dimensional phases.  

The PI will focus on the following issues. Fermionic atoms moving in three-dimensional optical lattices in the presence of Feshbach resonances can form states such as a paired superfluid, a band insulator and molecular Mott insulators. Precise phase diagrams encompassing these phases will be worked out. In two-dimensional optical lattices, topological superfluids can arise if one works with p-wave Feshbach resonances. When placed in optical lattices, transitions among various topological superfluids are possible, in a phase diagram which is expected to be rich and lead to more stable topological superfluids. The PI will investigate whether and how this happens. The PI will use a variety of methods to explore whether new phases occur in one dimensional lattices. These include the Fulde-Ferrell-Larkin-Ovchinnikov state as well as unusual states with decoupled quasicondensates. 

The PI will also study topological insulators which can be created with the ultracold atoms placed in lattices with topological band structure. The PI aims to find unconventional insulators which were not observed in materials. These can be obtained with the help of a variety of spin-orbit coupling techniques developed in the field. Different setups for these insulators will be investigated theoretically.

The PI will educate students across institutions through the Boulder Summer School on Condensed Matter and Materials Physics and other summer school activities within the United states and abroad.

NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY 

This award supports theoretical research and education with the aim to study matter and new phases of matter that arise in systems of many interacting atoms or electrons. Not all phases investigated theoretically have been or can be found in real materials because of difficulties in controlling the environment of the electrons or because they require special types of interactions that are difficult or impossible to realize through electrons in materials. Cold atoms trapped in lattices of laser light offer a way to simulate existing materials and create new states of matter. Atoms, whose interactions can be controlled in real time, can be trapped in an optical lattice created by lasers, cooled to very low temperatures, and made to behave like electrons do in solids or as hypothetical particles in theoretical models.  The results of these 'simulations' can then be used to guide investigations seeking new states of matter in materials. 

This research will focus on studying the phases of cold atoms in optical lattices in the presence of strong interactions. The interplay of the interaction of atoms with the lattices formed by lasers and the interaction of atoms with each other, gives rise to a variety of states of matter. The PI will develop a kind of 'roadmap' showing which phases are possible for given interaction strengths. Some of the most exciting phases possible in lattices are topological insulators, some of which have been observed in materials made of, for example the elements bismuth and selenium. However many more types of topological insulator are predicted but have not yet been observed in materials. This research will explore ways to make them with cold atoms. 

The PI will educate students across institutions through the Boulder Summer School on Condensed Matter and Materials Physics and other summer school activities within the United states and abroad.

por.por_cntn:
The ultimate goal of condensed matter and materials physics is to discover new materials with new properties which can be used in technological applications. The materials are made out of interacting electrons and atoms, arranged in a pattern of a crystalline lattice. The crystalline lattice forms spontaneously, due to the forces naturally existing between atoms and electrons. It was realized over a decade ago that it is alternatively possible to artificially manipulate certain atoms into forming lattices within a laser beam. This received the name of optical lattices. This method allows to create artificial “materials” which either mimic the properties of conventional materials or have properties not yet anticipated or observed. The typical distance between the atoms in a laser beam is orders of magnitude larger than in conventional materials, as a result they need to be kept at extraordinary low temperature to form stable lattices; hence the colloquial name “cold atoms” to describe these kinds of systems. This project aimed at examining various phases of matter possible with cold atoms.

 

The first class of artificial matter this project examined is artificial superconductors. Superconductors are distinguished by their ability to conduct electricity without resistance, and are usually formed by electrons when there are attractive interactions between electrons. In conventional materials these interactions are weak, so the superconductivity is a fragile phenomenon which prevented its widespread usage in power lines, for example. Cold atoms have interactions which can be artificially controlled and made arbitrarily strong. The first goal of this project was elucidating the conditions which induce the cold atoms placed in optical lattice with attractive interactions to form a superconductor, and to study the physical properties of this superconductor. This was carried out and the phase diagram of such a superconductor was constructed.

 

A remarkable feature of states of cold atoms is that they can be easily “shaken”, driven out of equilibrium, by an external force. This can be achieved simply by the application of an extra laser beam for a short time, or by changing the magnetic field in which the atoms reside rapidly. This led to the explosion of theoretical and experimental studies of out of equilibrium matter, which was not experimentally accessible until recently.  This project examined such out of equilibrium artificial superconductors and found new stationary phases accessible only via cold atoms in optical lattices. Those could be reached if the interactions among the atoms which formed this superconductor changes rapidly. Some of the most interesting superconductors are termed topological superconductors, and considerable resources are spent trying to create these in experiment. This work showed how a topological superconductor can be obtained by sudden change in the interactions between the atoms.

 

In a related project, the dynamics of a Bose-Einstein condensate whose interactions were suddenly changed was studied theoretically in collaboration with experimentalists at the University of Chicago who actually carried out this experiment. The waves created in the Bose-Einstein condensate by this sudden change in interactions are reminiscent to the dynamics of the early Universe undergoing inflation which led to the currently observed microwave background radiation anisotropy. This was published in the journal Science.

 

When quantum particles move through the random environment they may undergo a phenomenon called Anderson localization, where bouncing off many imperfections confines a quantum particle in space. Anderson localization is understood very well, and was observed experimentally. In the course of this work it was discovered that localization in a 5 dimensional world may proceed in a way which is very different from conventional Anderson localization. This was termed “higher-dimensional Anderson localization”. It would not be possible to do experiments in a five-dimensional space. However, a model was developed in the course of this work which has already been studied in the lab using cold atoms. That model involves atoms arranged along a single line, with varying interactions between them. This model was shown to realize the higher-dimensional localization avoiding the need to be in a high-dimensional space. This model was studied and its properties elucidated.

 

In the course of this work, two summer schools in Boulder CO were organized by the PI. One on the disorder and dynamics of quantum systems in 2013, and another on topological states in quantum matter in 2016, both subjects related to the research topics of this work. A large number of graduate students from the US and around the world were exposed to the ideas some of which developed in the course of this work. A Kavli Institute for Theoretical Physics program on out of equilibrium dynamics was also organized in 2012.  Finally in 2015 the PI spoke to an audience of international students including students from developing countries at the summer school in Khiva, Uzbekistan, organized by the International Center For Theoretical Physics in Trieste, Italy.
